publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Whether Hamilton's Bawn shall be turnd into a Barrack or Malt House
Thus spoke to my Lady── ye knight full of Care──
Let me have your advice── in A weighty affair
This Hamiltons Bawn while it sticks on my hand
I loose by ye house── what I get by the land
But how to dispose of it── to ye best Bidder
For A Barrack── or Malt-House── we now must consider
First let me Suppose── I make it a Malt-House
Here, I have computed ye proffit will fall t'us
There's nine hundred Pound for Labour── and Grain
I encrease it to twelve── so three Hundred remain
A handsome addition── for Wine── and good Chear
Three Dishes A Day── and three Hogsheads a year
Wtḥ a dozen large vessells my Vault shall be stor'd
No little Scrub Joint── shall come to my Board
And you── and ye Dean no more shall combine
To stint me att night── to one bottle of wine
Nor shall I, for his Humour── allow you to purloyn
A stone── and A half of Beef from my Sr·loyn
If I make it A Barrack── the Crown is my Tenant
My dear I have ponderd── and ponderd again on't
In poundage── and Draw-backs I loose half my rent
And whatever they give me── I must be content
Or Joyn wtḥ ye Court── in ev'ry debate
And rather than that── I woud loose my Estate
Thus ended ye knight── thus began his meek wife
It must── and it shall be A Barrack my life
I'm grown A meer Mopus── no Company comes
But A rable of Tenants── and rusty dull Rum's
Wtḥ Parsons── what Lady can keep herself clean
I'm all over dawb'd── When I sitt by ye Dean
om.
om.
But if you will give us A Barrack my Dear
The Captain I'm sure will always be here──
I then shall not value his Deanship A straw
For ye Captain I warrant will keep him in Awe
Or shḍ he pretend to be brisk── and Alert
Will tell him── yt Chaplains── should not be so pert
That men of his Coat── shoud be minding their Prayrs
And not among Ladys── to give themselves Airs
Thus Argu'd my Lady── but argu'd in vain
The Knight── his Opinion resolv'd to maintain
But Hannah── who listn'd to all that had past
And coud not endure── so vulgar A taste
As soon as her ladyship calld to be dress'd
Cry'd Madam── why sure my Master's possessd
Sr Arthur── ye Maltster── how fine it will sound
I'de rather ye Bawn── was sunk under ground
But Madam── I guessd there wou'd never come good

When I saw him so often── wth
Darby── and Wood──·two of sr Arthur's Stewards─.
And now my dream's out── for I was adream'd
That I saw A huge Rat── oh dear how I scream'd
And after── methought── I had lost my new Shoes
And Molly── She said── I shou'd hear some ill news──
Dear Madam── had you but ye spirit to teize
You might have A Barrack── whenever you please
And Madam── I alway's believ'd you so stout
That for twenty denyals── you would not give out
If I had A Husband like him── I protest
Till he gave me my Will── I wou'd give him no rest
And rather── than come in ye same pair of sheets
Wtḥ such A cross man── I woud lie in the Streets
But Madam── I beg you── contrive── and invent
And worry him out── till he gives his consent
Dear Madam── whene'er of A Barrack I think
An I were to be hang'd, I can't sleep A wink
For if A new Crotchet comes into my brain
I cant get it out── tho Id never so fain
I fancy already A Barrack contriv'd
At Hamiltons Bawn── and ye Troop is arriv'd
Of this to be sure── Sr Arthur has warning
And waits on ye Captain, betimes the next morning
Now see── when they meet── how their Honours behave
Noble Captain ye servant── Sr Arthur your Slave
You honour me much── the Honour is mine
Twas A sad rainy Night── but ye morning is fine
Pray how does my Lady── my Wifes att your Service
I think I have once seen her Picture att Jarvis
Good Morrow── good Captain── I'le wait on you down
You shant stir A foot── you'l think me A Clown
For all ye World Captain── not half an inch farther
You must be obeyd── yr Servant Sr Arthur
My humble respects── to my Lady unknown
I hope you will use my house── as yr own
Go bring me my Smock── and leave of your prate
Thou hast certainly got A Cup in thy Pate
Pray Madam be quiet── what was it I said
You had like to have putt it── quite out of my head
Next day to be sure ye Captain will come
At ye head of his troop, wtḥ Trumpet── and Drum
Now madam── observe how he marches in State
The Man wtḥ ye Kettledrum Enters ye Gate
Dub── Dub── Dub── the Trumpeter's follow
Tantara── tantara── while all ye boys hollow

See now comes ye Captain all dawbd wth
gold lace
O law── ye sweet Gentleman look in his face
And see how he rides── like A Lord of the Land
What A fine flaming Sword do's he hold in his hand
And his Horse── the dear Creature── it prances and rears
Wtḥ ribbans in knotts att his Tail── and his Ears
At last comes ye Troop── by ye word of Command
Drawn up in our Court── till ye Captain crys── Stand
Your Ladyship lifts up the Sash── to be seen
(for sure I had dizend you out── like A Queen)
The Captain to shew he was proud of the favour
Looks up att yr Window── and cocks up his Beavor
His Beavor is Cockd── pray Madam mark that
For A Captain of horse── never pulls of his Hatt
Because he has never A hand yt is idle
For ye Right holds his Sword── and ye left holds his bridle)
Then flourishes thrice his Sword in the Air
As A Complement due to A Lady so fair
How I tremble to think── of ye blood it has spilt
Then he lowers down ye Point── and kisses ye Hilt
Your Ladyship smiles── and thus── you begin────
Pray Captain be pleasd── to alight── and walk in
The Captain salutes you wtḥ Congee profound
And yr Ladyship Curtsies half way to the ground
Kit run to yr Master── and bid him── come to us
Jm sure he'll be proud of ye honour you do us
And Captain── youl do us ye favour to stay
And take A short dinner here wtḥ us to day
You're heartily wellcome── but as for good chear
You come in ye very worst time of ye year
Had I but expected so worthy A Guest────
Lord! Madam! your Ladyship sure is in jest
You banter me Madam, the Kingdom must grant────
You officers Captain, are so── complaisant
Hist Hussy── I think I hear somebody Coming.
No Madam── 'tis only Sr Arthur A humming
To shorten my Tale──── for I hate A long Story
The Captain att dinner appears in his glory
The Dean── and ye Doctor have humbled their pride
For── ye Captain's entreated to Sitt by your Side
And because he's their Betters── you carve for him first
The Parson's for Envy── are ready to burst
The Servants amaz'd, are scarce ever able
To keep off their Eyes as they wait att ye Table
And Molly── and I── do thrust in our nose
To peep att ye Captain in all his fine cloaths
Dear Madam── besure he's A fine spoken man
Do but hear on ye Clergyman, how his tongue ran
om.
om.
And Madam says he── if such dinners you give
Youl never want Parsons── as long as you live

I neer knew A Parson── wth
out A good Nose
But ye Devills as wellcome wherever he goes
G──d-d──me they bid us reform, and repent
But zo──ds by their looks they never keep lent
Mr Curate, for all yr grave looks── Im afraid
You cast A sheep's Eye── on her Ladyships Maid
I wish she woud lend you── her lilly white hand
In mending yr Gown── and smoothing yr band
For ye Dean was so shabby── and lookd like a Ninny
The Captain supposd, he was Curate to Jenny──·Dr Jenny, A Clergy man att Ardmagh.
Whenever you see A Cassock, and Gown
A Hundred to one── but it covers A Clown
Observe how A Parson comes into A room
G──d d──me he hobles as bad as my Groom
A Schollard when just from ye Colledge broke loose
Can hardly tell how to cry Bo── to A Goose
Your Novids── and Blutrachs── and Omars, and Stuff
By G──d── they dont signifie this pinch of Snuff
To give A young Gentleman right education
The Army's the very best School in ye Nation
My Schooll-Master calld me A Dunce── and A Fool
But att Cuffs── I was always ye Cock of the schooll
I never could take to my book for the blood o'me
And ye Puppy confess'd, he expected no good o'me
om.
om.
om.
om.
Now Madam── you'l think it A strange thing to say
But ye sight of A Book── makes me sick to this day
Never since I was born── did I hear so much Witt
And Madam I thought── I shd laugh till I splitt
So then you look'd scornfull── and Miffd att the Dean
As who shḍ say── now am I skinny and lean
But he durst not so much── as open his lips
And ye Doctor was plaguely down in the Hips
Thus merciless Hannah ran on in her talk
Till she heard── ye Dean call── will yr Ladyship walk
────Her ladyship answers Im just coming down
Then turning to Hannah── and forcing A frown
Altho' it was plain, in her heart she was glad
Cryd Hussy, why sure── ye wench is run mad
How coud those Chimeras get into your brains
Come hither── and take this old gown for yr pains
But ye Dean── shd this secret come once to his Ears

Will never have done── wth
his Gibes── and his Jeers
For yr life not A word of the Matter I charge ye
Give me but A Barrack── and·A fig for ye Clergy────
